security_audit.summary: This is a pure markdown documentation skill containing only guidance for Go programming patterns. No executable code, network calls, filesystem access, or command execution capabilities exist. All 64 static findings are false positives: SHA256 content hashes in metadata were misidentified as cryptographic code, Go code examples using backticks for multi-line strings were misidentified as shell execution, and environment variable loading examples were misidentified as credential access. The previous audit on 2026-01-10 correctly assessed this as safe with no risk factors.

content.user_title: Apply Go best practices for type-safe code
content.value_statement: Go projects often suffer from runtime errors that could be caught at compile time. This skill provides patterns for type-first development, interfaces, functional options, and proper error handling to prevent bugs before they happen.
actual_capabilities: Guide type-first development with custom types and structs
Implement functional options pattern for flexible configuration
Apply proper error handling with context and wrapping
Structure Go modules with cohesive package design
Create exhaustive switch statements with default error handling
limitations: Does not execute or test Go code
Does not provide compiler or tooling
Does not integrate with Go modules or dependencies
Does not generate complete project scaffolds

use_cases.title: Write type-safe Go code
use_cases.description: Design data structures and interfaces before implementation to make illegal states unrepresentable.

use_cases.title: Build maintainable APIs
use_cases.description: Create clean error handling patterns and functional options for configurable server implementations.

use_cases.title: Generate idiomatic Go
use_cases.description: Follow established Go conventions when writing or reviewing Go code for any project.

prompt_templates.title: Basic type design
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a type-safe Go struct for a [entity] with proper custom types for domain primitives. Include validation at construction and proper error handling.

prompt_templates.title: Interface definition
prompt_templates.prompt: Define a Go interface for a [repository/service] that accepts context and returns typed results. Show how to accept interfaces and return structs.

prompt_templates.title: Functional options
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement a NewServer function using the functional options pattern with sensible defaults. Include examples for port, timeout, and custom configuration.

prompt_templates.title: Complete implementation
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement a complete Go package following type-first development: define types first, create interfaces, implement error wrapping with %w, and add table-driven tests.

output_examples.input: Create a User type with email validation and proper error handling
output: Define UserID as a custom string type to prevent ID confusion
Create User struct with embedded Timestamps for tracking
Implement NewUser function that validates email format
Use fmt.Errorf with %w for error wrapping
Add exhaustive switch with default error case

output_examples.input: Create a server with custom port and timeout configuration
output: Define ServerOption as a function type for configuration
Create WithPort and WithTimeout option functions
Implement NewServer with default values (port 8080, 30s timeout)
Apply all options in a loop for flexible configuration

output_examples.input: Design an interface for a user repository
output: Define UserRepository interface with GetByID and Save methods
Accept context.Context in each method for cancellation
Return typed results with (*User, error) signatures
Accept interfaces in functions, return concrete structs

best_practices: Define types and interfaces before implementation to let the compiler guide completeness.
Accept interfaces, return structs to maximize flexibility while controlling API surface.
Return new values instead of mutating inputs to make data flow explicit.
anti_patterns: Using generic types like string or int instead of domain-specific custom types.
Returning errors without context using bare errors.New without wrapping.
Skipping default cases in switch statements, allowing silent failures.

faq.question: Does this skill work with Go 1.18+ generics?
faq.answer: Yes. The patterns focus on type-first development. Generics can complement custom types when appropriate.

faq.question: What Go versions are supported?
faq.answer: Go 1.17 and later. Error wrapping with %w requires Go 1.13+.

faq.question: Can this integrate with my existing Go project?
faq.answer: This is a prompt skill. It guides AI assistants working on your code but does not modify files directly.

faq.question: Is any data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: No. This skill contains only documentation patterns. No network calls or data transmission occurs.

faq.question: How does this compare to golangci-lint?
faq.answer: This skill provides design patterns. golangci-lint enforces code quality. Use both together.

faq.question: Should I use this for every Go file?
faq.answer: Load this skill when working with Go files. The patterns apply to most Go code you write.
